RuleEngine Project Description 1: The RuleEngine was an administrative webtool that I had to design together with another intern for my internship at VanGenechten. The application was meant to be used to quickly configure the factory sensors with specific rules and alerts. The application was designed entire in React Javascript, with the components designed in Bit.Dev React, a TypeScript-based component framework. The components we created had to be reusable in the future without requiring extensive knowledge of react, and as such would have to automatically generate fields, rows and control elements based on the input of the component.
RuleEngine Project Description 2: Being the more experienced of the two interns (with the second intern being from the graduate course), I was in charge of the more technically taxing tasks of the project, such as carrying out the functional analysis, writing the code for the automatic generation of elements and the architecture of our pages, and writing scripts for code automation and database testing.
CodeFarm Project Description 1: 'CodeFarm' was our internal name for the Project 4.0 course semester project. We had gotten the task from VITO RemoteSense to design an app with which you could take pictures on a phone of strawberry flowers, count them using image recognition and then save and visualize this information on a dashboard. The project consisted out of a 3 month long preparation period where we did all the appropriate research, design and planning, and a 3-week long realization phase where everyone was present full-time to work on the project.
CodeFarm Project Description 2: For this project, we worked in a multi-disciplinary, international team of 2 front-end specialists, 2 AI-specialists and 2 cybersecurity specialists. Within the front-end team we worked with a 2-pass system, where the other programmer was in charge of rapid integration, creating quick barebones versions of our pages which could immediately be used for integration and testing by the other teams, while I polished these sections by cleaning up the code, improving the look and feel and bringing it in line with the rest of the application style-wise.

GemTD Project Description 1: During my graduate degree, I dabbled a lot with game development coding. I first started on the Monogame framework where I designed a simple geometric based platformer, but then moved on to Unity to try something better documented. I earned the Junior Unity Programmer badge, and after a few missed attempts, I created a reinvisioning of an old flash game I used to play; GemTD, a tower defence game where every turn you would get 5 minerals to place on the map and have all but one of them revert into rocks. These would then act as persistent obstacles for the enemies you'd have to defend against, and across the many turns you could eventually craft elaborate mazes to keep enemies off the checkpoints for as long as possible.
